Last king of the Two Sicilies, ruling from 1859 to 1861, known for his brief and tumultuous reign that ended with the unification of Italy.

Written by: Victor Malone

Francis II of the Two Sicilies: The Last King of a Fading Dynasty

Known for His Brief but Turbulent Reign

Francis II of the Two Sicilies was the last king of the Kingdom of the Two Sicilies, ruling from 1859 to 1861. He is remembered for his brief but tumultuous reign, marked by internal strife, external threats, and ultimately, the downfall of his dynasty.

Early Life and Education

Born on January 16, 1836, in Naples, Francis II was the only son of King Ferdinand II of the Two Sicilies and his first wife, Maria Christina of Savoy. His education was neglected, and he grew up to be a man of weak character, heavily influenced by his stepmother, Archduchess Maria Theresa of Austria, and the reactionary court.

Marriage and Family

On February 3, 1859, Francis II married Duchess Maria Sophie of Bavaria, a younger sister of Empress Elisabeth of Austria. The marriage was unhappy, and their only daughter, Maria Cristina, was born ten years after their wedding. Tragically, she lived only three months, from December 24, 1869, to March 28, 1870.

Reign and Downfall

Francis II took the throne on May 22, 1859, after the death of his father. During his reign, he appointed Carlo Filangieri as prime minister, who advised him to accept the alliance with the Kingdom of Sardinia proposed by Cavour. However, Francis II's reign was marked by internal unrest, and on June 7, 1859, a part of the Swiss Guard mutinied. The incident resulted in the disbanding of the whole Swiss Guard, which was the strongest bulwark of the Bourbon dynasty.

The End of the Kingdom

The Kingdom of the Two Sicilies was eventually merged into the newly formed Kingdom of Italy, following successive invasions by Giuseppe Garibaldi and Victor Emmanuel II of Sardinia. Francis II was deposed, and his kingdom was absorbed into the new Italian state.

Legacy

Francis II of the Two Sicilies is remembered as the last king of a fading dynasty, whose reign was marked by internal strife and external threats. His downfall marked the end of the Kingdom of the Two Sicilies and the beginning of a new era in Italian history.

Trivia and Fun Facts

Francis II was known as "Francischieddu" in Neapolitan dialect.

He was the last of the Bourbon kings of Naples.

His marriage to Maria Sophie of Bavaria was unhappy and childless for ten years.

Comparative Analysis with Contemporaries

Francis II's reign was marked by internal weakness and external pressures, unlike his contemporaries, such as Victor Emmanuel II of Sardinia, who successfully united Italy under his rule.

Influence on Modern Society

The fall of the Kingdom of the Two Sicilies and the rise of the Kingdom of Italy marked a significant shift in Italian history and politics. Francis II's reign may have been short, but its impact on modern society is still felt today.

Conclusion

Francis II of the Two Sicilies was a king of contrasts, marked by both weakness and determination. His brief but tumultuous reign marked the end of an era and the beginning of a new chapter in Italian history.

FAQ

What was Francis II of the Two Sicilies role in the unification of Italy?

Francis II of the Two Sicilies served as the King of the Two Sicilies during the tumultuous period of Italian unification, ultimately surrendering to the forces of Giuseppe Garibaldi and Victor Emmanuel II.

What was Francis II of the Two Sicilies relationship like with Giuseppe Garibaldi?

Francis II of the Two Sicilies had a complex and often antagonistic relationship with Giuseppe Garibaldi, the Italian revolutionary leader who ultimately defeated him and unified Italy.

What was Francis II of the Two Sicilies role in the development of the Kingdom of the Two Sicilies?

Francis II of the Two Sicilies worked to modernize and develop the Kingdom of the Two Sicilies, introducing reforms and promoting economic growth and development.

What was Francis II of the Two Sicilies stance on liberalism and democracy?

Francis II of the Two Sicilies was a strong opponent of liberalism and democracy, believing in the absolute power of monarchs and the importance of preserving traditional social and political structures.

What legacy did Francis II of the Two Sicilies leave behind?

Francis II of the Two Sicilies left behind a legacy as the last King of the Two Sicilies, as well as a symbol of the old monarchical order that was ultimately swept away by the forces of liberal democracy and nationalism.
